intro: Nassauvia pyramidalis, commonly known as the pyramid bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its compact growth habit and ornamental flowers make it a popular choice for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Nassauvia pyramidalis is also valued for its drought tolerance and ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
